history.content:
Based on the information you gave about yourself in this post, I'd say 170 would probably be a heavier workload for you than 61b was (assuming you're going to put in all the effort necessary to fully grasp the concepts). I took 170 after having taken the "prereqs" and I spent ~12 hours on the homework each week and another 2 or 3 reviewing material from that week. Of course, every person is different, so I'm sure if you really put yourself to it you'd be just fine in the class!

----

CS170 takes 20 hrs/week *with* 61B and 70 experience. It doesn't make sense in general to skip classes. You might think 'oh it's just proofs' but how you write the proof is most (70%+) of the points on the exams sometimes even if you can grasp the answer.

----

Another person chiming in here. I think it depends on your mathematical maturity so to speak, but given that you haven't taken 70 yet, even if you are good at math, you may not have yet been exposed to the type of math and rigor that is needed for 170 (introduced in 70). While the material builds more upon 61B material (like search, and a little bit of hashing) compared to 70 material. I think that 170 builds more upon 70 in the sense of expectation, rigor, and theoretical approach. 70 builds the foundation that you need to tackle 170. I consider myself more of a mathy person, but I found that 170 took more time than 61B but less time than 70 (but I had a solid foundation from 70).

Based on the information you gave about yourself in this post, I'd say 170 would probably be a heavier workload for you than 61b was (assuming you're going to put in all the effort necessary to fully grasp the concepts). I took 170 after having taken the "prereqs" and I spent ~12 hours on the homework each week and another 2 or 3 reviewing material from that week. Of course, every person is different, so I'm sure if you really put yourself to it you'd be just fine in the class!

----

CS170 takes 20 hrs/week *with* 61B and 70 experience. It doesn't make sense in general to skip classes. You might think 'oh it's just proofs' but how you write the proof is most (70%+) of the points on the exams sometimes even if you can grasp the answer.

Based on the information you gave about yourself in this post, I'd say 170 would probably be a heavier workload for you than 61b was (assuming you're going to put in all the effort necessary to fully grasp the concepts). I took 170 after having taken the "prereqs" and I spent ~12 hours on the homework each week and another 2 or 3 reviewing material from that week. Of course, every person is different, so I'm sure if you really put yourself to it you'd be just fine in the class!

Is there a correlation between the amount of time invested in 61b vs 170?  

I went into 61b w/out much programming experience and it was a steep learning curve which required on average about 20+ hrs/week.  I won't have as much time next semester to solely invest in a single class so I'm trying to get a gauge on how much time CS170 would take.  I know CS170 doesn't involve much programming but it builds on concepts introduced in 61b, which was a time consuming class for me.  I haven't taken 70 and have heard the necessary parts are the graph theory exposure & proof writing skills; I've read How to Prove It but haven't taken a discrete math course.  All things considered, should I assume CS170 would take about the same amount of time as 61b for me?  possibly more? 

Thank you!
history.subject: 61b vs 170 workload and taking 170 without 70?
